metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: XML documents can have a reference to a DTD or to an XML Schema.
content.html: XML documents can have a reference to a DTD or to an XML Schema.

content.text: Look at this simple XML document called "note.xml":
content.html: Look at this simple XML document called "note.xml":

content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<note>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

content.text: The following example is a DTD file called "note.dtd" that defines the elements of the XML document above ("note.xml"):
content.html: The following example is a DTD file called "note.dtd" that defines the elements of the XML document above ("note.xml"):

content.code:
<!ELEMENT note (to, from, heading, body)>

<!ELEMENT to (#PCDATA)>

<!ELEMENT from (#PCDATA)>

<!ELEMENT heading (#PCDATA)>

<!ELEMENT body (#PCDATA)>
content.code_html:
<!ELEMENT note (to, from, heading, body)>
<!ELEMENT to (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT from (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT heading (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT body (#PCDATA)>

content.text: The first line defines the note element to have four child elements: "to, from, heading, body".
content.html: The first line defines the note element to have four child elements: "to, from, heading, body".

content.text: Line 2-5 defines the to, from, heading, body elements to be of type "#PCDATA".
content.html: Line 2-5 defines the to, from, heading, body elements to be of type "#PCDATA".

content.text: The following example is an XML Schema file called "note.xsd" that defines the elements of the XML document above ("note.xml"):
content.html: The following example is an XML Schema file called "note.xsd" that defines the elements of the XML document above ("note.xml"):

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
targetNamespace="https://www.w3schools.com"
xmlns="https://www.w3schools.com"
elementFormDefault="qualified">


<xs:element name="note">


<xs:complexType>


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element name="to" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="from" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="heading" type="xs:string"/>


<xs:element name="body" type="xs:string"/>


</xs:sequence>


</xs:complexType>

</xs:element>


</xs:schema>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<xs:schema xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
targetNamespace="https://www.w3schools.com"
xmlns="https://www.w3schools.com"
elementFormDefault="qualified">

<xs:element name="note">
  <xs:complexType>
    <xs:sequence>
      <xs:element name="to" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="from" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="heading" type="xs:string"/>
      <xs:element name="body" type="xs:string"/>
    </xs:sequence>
  </xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

</xs:schema>

content.text: The note element is a complex type because it contains other elements. The other elements (to, from, heading, body) are simple types because they do not contain other elements. You will learn more about simple and complex types in the following chapters.
content.html: The note element is a complex type because it contains other elements. The other elements (to, from, heading, body) are simple types because they do not contain other elements. You will learn more about simple and complex types in the following chapters.

content.text: This XML document has a reference to a DTD:
content.html: This XML document has a reference to a DTD:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0"?>


<!DOCTYPE note SYSTEM
"https://www.w3schools.com/xml/note.dtd">


<note>


<to>Tove</to>


<from>Jani</from>


<heading>Reminder</heading>


<body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>

</note>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<!DOCTYPE note SYSTEM
"https://www.w3schools.com/xml/note.dtd">

<note>
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>

content.text: A Reference to an XML Schema
This XML document has a reference to an XML Schema:
content.html: This XML document has a reference to an XML Schema:

content.code:
<?xml version="1.0"?>


<note
xmlns="https://www.w3schools.com"
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:schemaLocation="https://www.w3schools.com/xml note.xsd">
 
<to>Tove</to>


<from>Jani</from>


<heading>Reminder</heading>


<body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>

</note>
content.code_html:
<?xml version="1.0"?>

<note
xmlns="https://www.w3schools.com"
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:schemaLocation="https://www.w3schools.com/xml note.xsd">
  <to>Tove</to>
  <from>Jani</from>
  <heading>Reminder</heading>
  <body>Don't forget me this weekend!</body>
</note>
